Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Commercialization of the Video Collaboratory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project team is developing a web-based application designed for small group collaboration around video artifacts. Beyond simply viewing video, this application is equipped to allow users to dive in and analyze and annotate the video and to have discussions around the video artifact while either co-located or distributed. The application is designed to be a system that has features to enhance collaborative sense-making around video. There are few other systems designed for groups of people to privately work with video artifacts to transform the data embedded in video content into information and knowledge that can be used in creative pursuits and in analytics and decision making.

The commercialization of this technology has the potential for broad societal impacts. Video capture is already ubiquitous and is only increasing, leading to millions of hours of video that is under-utilized across a wide spectrum of domains. This system, if made widely available through commercialization, can help people to work with video to transform the data in their video content into information and knowledge. The technology enables collaborative sense-making that can lead to more creative outcomes in art and design domains and to better understanding and better decision makings in complex environments such as medicine, science and defense.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Title: I-Corps: Commercialization of the Video Collaboratory

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

Developed by University researchers, the Video Collaboratory (VC) is a software platform designed for small groups to collaborate and discuss information contained in a video format. As with collaboration around text documents, the Video Collaboratory allows asynchronous, distributed access, making it a convenient and efficient work tool. With various interaction and collaboration support features such as text commenting and sketching on the video frames, variable speed control and looping, the VC uses the power of the Internet to move collaborative projects forward more quickly without sacrificing detail and specificity. Part of this grant was used to further the education of two graduate students who participated in the technology transfer and entrepreneurial process and also worked towards refining the platform.

Participation in the I-Corps program provided the VC team with training and experiences with which to realistically assess the future commercialization of the software. During the rigorous 8-week program, the 5-member Video Collaboratory team interviewed 100 prospective customers whose responses helped in the determination to commercialize the VC system. Workers in a variety of areas such as education, medicine, physical therapy, video production, sports and performing arts indicated that the VC system would be of help in their jobs. The team gained a much better understanding of the choices, implications, steps and pitfalls in the interrelated entrepreneurial process, based on the education delivered by I-Corps faculty about the financial, legal and marketing components. All of this information provided the perspective necessary to make an informed decision to move forward with translating the research into a commercial ready state.

Participation in the I-Corps program led to acceptance in Groundwork Labs, a start-up incubator in Durham, NC, where the VC team was able to build upon the I-Corps knowledge and experiences. After beta-testing the VC system in a variety of domains, the Video Collaboratory research team formed a Limited Liability Corporation in North Carolina in January 2015 as the first phase of technology transfer. Based on feedback from early adopters, the team is currently bridging technology gaps necessary to bring the software to a commercial ready state. The Video Collaboratory, LLC plans to launch in 2016.


Last Modified: 07/30/2015
Modified by: Celine Latulipe
